image.altText: A skier goes past a snow gun

props.synopsis: Many of the world's ski field operators now rely on snow machines to guarantee business, but others say the practice uses too much water and risks environmental harm.Â

title.children: Snow guns prove Ben Lomond ski field 'very viable' as park considers future

image.altText: A diagram of two frogs, one with tadpoles in it's belly, and another with a frog in it's mouth.

props.synopsis: Nearly two decades ago, scientists in Newcastle came surprisingly close to resurrecting the extinct gastric brooding frog. Their failure highlights issues still plaguing de-extinction research today.

title.children: How a team of Australian scientists almost brought back an extinct frog and has sights on the thylacine

image.altText: A colourised photo of a Tasmanian tiger.

props.synopsis: Even after a long life, Peggie Bassett can still remember the guttural growl and striking scent of the last known thylacine as it prowled its concrete enclosure.

title.children: Peggie saw a thylacine as a child. She wouldn't ever want to 'go back and see it'

props.synopsis: People were playing in the snow in southern Tasmania, with it settling as low as 150 metres in some spots, but warmer conditions are on the way. The weekend will bring more spring-typical weather for Father's Day.

title.children: Snow drops to 150m in chilly first week of spring in Tasmania

image.altText: An image of a potato cut in half with rust coloured arcs inside on its flesh.

props.synopsis: Victoria, New South Wales and South Australia have placed restrictions on the importation of unprocessed Tasmanian potatoes, following the island state's outbreak of mop-top virus.

title.children: Ban on potato exports from Tasmania to Vic, NSW, SA over mop-top virus

image.altText: man looks neutrally at camera

props.synopsis: There are calls to expand the eligibility of a workplace justice program that allows visa holders to extend their stay while they are pursuing workplace exploitations claims.

title.children: Wages going unpaid as visa workers try to keep their 'head down'

image.altText: A sad child sits in a chair with their face hidden behind their hair

props.synopsis: There can be a range of clues parents can pick up on when their child is being bullied. Here's how to approach it with your child, and how to advocate for them at school.

title.children: What if your child is being bullied, but the school won't act?

image.altText: A small pile of sand and rubbish, including microplastics.

props.synopsis: Tasmania's east coast town of Coles Bay was the first in Australia to ban single-use plastic bags in 2003. How did we go from nation leader to lagger? Airlie Ward talks with reporter Meg Whitfield.

title.children: TassieCast: Why are we yet to ban single-use plastics?

props.synopsis: Labor's Ella Haddad tells ABC Stateline Tasmania integrity is wanting under the Liberal state government.

title.children: Integrity system broken under Liberals, says Haddad

image.altText: Bronson Xerri in a Canterbury-Bankstown Bulldogs NRL jersey walking alongside two trainers

props.synopsis: The Bulldogs and Sharks needed to get out of their NRL showdown unscathed, but injury and judiciary concerns abound for both after Cronulla's 24-6 win.

title.children: Sharks thump Dogs but both teams face nervous wait on finals eve

image.altText: Molly Wilkes with her mother Julie Adams.

props.synopsis: Perpetrators of domestic violence and financial abuse can gain access to the superannuation benefits and life insurance proceeds of their victims. A parliamentary inquiry finds super laws should be changed to prevent it continuing.

title.children: The 'shocking' loophole allowing some abusers to profit from partners' deaths

image.altText: A close up photo shows the face of Xi Jinping.

props.synopsis: China's display of an array of naval weaponry and assets, as opposed to land-based ones, could hardly have been less subtle.

title.children: As a new world order dawns, Australia plods along, much to scholars' dismay

image.altText: a view of St Patrick's Catholic cathedral in East Melbourne

props.synopsis: An ABC investigation can reveal the Catholic Church tried to revive a highly controversial legal loophole that stopped it from being sued by victims of sexual abuse for millions of dollars in damages, after it was scrapped in 2018.

title.children: Catholic Church tried to revive outlawed legal loophole in abuse case

image.altText: A brown snake sticking its head out from under blankets

props.synopsis: A near-fatal bite was not enough to stop Queenslander Kasey Leadbetter from loving snakes but she says treatment could be improved, and researchers agree.

title.children: Nanny bitten by brown snake while sleeping calls for improved treatments

image.altText: A man in work clothes, wearing a cap and leaning on against an off-road vehicle.

props.synopsis: The trial of celebrity crocodile wrangler Matt Wright unearthed a culture of helicopter maintenance and safety breaches by his company, which some say have been ongoing in Australia's north for decades.

title.children: Cowboy helicopter culture exposed by Matt Wright trial

image.altText: Donald Trump holds up a signed document.

props.synopsis: The move is the latest step in Donald Trump's efforts to rebrand the US military, including by presiding over an extraordinary military parade in downtown Washington DC, and restoring the original names of military bases that were changed after racial justice protests in 2020.

title.children: Trump changes Department of Defense's name to Department of War

image.altText: The exteriorÂ of the Don Dale Youth Detention Centre, with barbed wire in the foreground.

props.synopsis: An Aboriginal child was held in a solitary cell for more than three days and denied food and medication as a coercion "strategy", an investigation into the NT's notorious Don Dale youth prison has found.

title.children: Child held in solitary cell for three days, denied food and medications

image.altText: Chalmers gestures while sitting at a table.

props.synopsis: This week in Canberra the government seemed to be getting cold feet on its superannuation tax plan and the Coalition reckoned Labor was being less than transparent.

title.children: Is Labor getting cold feet on its superannuation tax plan?

image.altText: Tennis star Jannik Sinner looks up at his coaches and clenches his fist in celebration at the US Open.

props.synopsis: It's a Carlos Alcaraz vs Jannik Sinner final for the third straight major, as the world number one advances after a tougher-than-expected challenge from Canada's Felix Auger-Aliassime.

title.children: It's Sinner vs Alcaraz again in the US Open final

image.altText: A man wearing a navy button-up top with a shaved head in front of a grey backdrop

props.synopsis: Hamas has released a video showing Israeli hostages Guy Gilboa-Dalal and Alon Ohel, who were captured during the militant group's October 7, 2023, attack.Â

title.children: Hamas releases video showing Israeli hostages

image.altText: Multiple firefighters attempt to douse large flames from a structure well alight

props.synopsis: Couples hoping to tie the knot at a popular wedding venue in the Hawkesbury are waking up to the news it has been destroyed.

title.children: Blaze destroys historic wedding venue in NSW Hawkesbury

image.altText: man with blurred face

props.synopsis: A 62-year-old man is arrested and charged after allegedly having 35 kilograms of methamphetamine, worth an estimated $11 million, in his luggage at Brisbane Airport.

title.children: Man arrested at airport after allegedly hiding $11m of meth in luggage

image.altText: Two women and a young boy sitting in a stadium, surrounded by other people.

props.synopsis: Buckingham Palace announces Katharine, Duchess of Kent â who once had a secret job as a primary school music teacher â died on Thursday evening.

title.children: Oldest member of British royal family, who once had secret job, dead at 92

image.altText: A painting of a green valley with shrubs on the side and a mountain in the background, in an ornate gold frame.g

props.synopsis: Russian artist Nicholas Chevalier's now-famous painting of Mt Abrupt in western Victoria is being used by a revegetation group to reflect the landscape as the artist saw it in 1864.

title.children: Clues in 161-year-old painting help restore Grampians' native beauty

image.altText: A man looks on during an A-League Men's match

props.synopsis: Western United's players are officially free agents with the club to be placed on ice for the next 12 months as they attempt to stave off extinction.Â

title.children: Western United enter hibernation as wind-up drags on

image.altText: Two protesters holding signs that read 'save our pool'.

props.synopsis: The Australian Medical Association has urged the state government to intervene in a Melbourne council's decision to close a swimming pool, warning of "serious and predictable" health consequences.

title.children: AMA calls on local council to reverse decision to close swimming pool

image.altText: A smiling, middle-aged man smiles while he takes a selfie with a girl, whose face is blurred.

props.synopsis: When Andrew Burow went missing from his Brisbane unit, it sparked an investigation full of twists and turns.

title.children: What we know about the mysterious disappearance of Andrew Burow

image.altText: A male dancer holds his hands up, taking a bow in front of an audience

props.synopsis: Years of hard work have led to Zai Calliste's upcoming debut performance with one of the world's elite dance companies.Â

title.children: At just 21, this Queenslander has danced his way to the London ballet

image.altText: Peter Allely sits in a dark studio with blue lights behind.

props.synopsis: A senior WA emergency department doctor describes his workplace as running in a "disaster situation", struggling within a health system which has an "unhealthy fixation" on ambulance ramping.

title.children: Senior doctor warns WA emergency departments run like 'disaster situation'

image.altText: A family at the kitchen table crowd around a birthday cake for a one year old in a vintage film photo.

props.synopsis: Some memories fade away, while others stay with us for life. But why can we remember some things and not others? And can you "make" a memory? This is what the experts say.

title.children: Do core memories really exist? We asked the experts

image.altText: Antonio Guterres speaks in front of the PNG flag.

props.synopsis: United Nations chief AntÃ³nio Guterres has refused to respond to comments telling him to "cut the crap" after a national newspaper criticised him for not calling out corruption in Papua New Guinea.

title.children: UN chief walks out on question over calls to 'cut the crap' on PNG visit

image.altText: two people walk along the Kerferd Road Pier, Albert Park

props.synopsis: The infamous variability of spring weather across southern Australia will be on full display during the coming week.

title.children: Major rain event to hit eastern states after a burst of spring heat

image.altText: Two smiling sibling in running gear at the start of race, with mountains in the background.

props.synopsis: A broken leg fails to stop a West Australian woman and her brother from taking on the gruelling La Petite Trotte Ã  LÃ©on through France, Italy and Switzerland.

title.children: Australian siblings take on 'brutal' alpine enduro race through Europe

image.altText: A composite image showing a chicken parmigiana, Cardi B and Reece Walsh

props.synopsis: This week's quiz features Reece Walsh, memories of an extinction, and a pub running out of _____.

title.children: Can you match what they said to the news? Time to tackle the ABC's Quote Quiz

image.altText: Two police officers stand inspecting something behind police tape.

props.synopsis: Authorities are searching for alleged police shooter Dezi Freeman in the north-east Victorian town of Porepunkah. Here's what we know about the search so far.Â

title.children: The timeline, faces and places in Porepunkah's police hunt
